unnormalised: Okay, so you're thinking about getting into Information Technology, huh? It's a pretty sweet field, ngl. But it's also HUGE! Like, seriously, where do you even start? Let's break it down a bit, especially if you're just starting out in India.
normalised: Okay, so you're thinking about getting into Information Technology, huh? It's a pretty sweet field, not gonna lie. But it's also huge! Like, seriously, where do you even start? Let's break it down a bit, especially if you're just starting out in India.

unnormalised: First things first, "IT" basically means dealing with computers and networks. Think everything from setting up your grandma’s Wi-Fi (which, by the way, uses the 2.4 GHz frequency band mostly, right?) to building complex software systems for companies like TCS or Infosys. The scope is vast, as they say.
normalised: First things first, I-T basically means dealing with computers and networks. Think everything from setting up your grandma’s Wi-Fi (which, by the way, uses the two point four Giga-hertz frequency band mostly, right?) to building complex software systems for companies like T-C-S or Infosys. The scope is vast, as they say.

unnormalised: Now, most people think about coding first, and yeah, programming is a big part of it. Languages like Python, Java, C++ are like the bread and butter of the industry. Seriously, learning Python will get you far, especially if you're interested in things like data science or AI/ML (Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning). And trust me, those fields are HOT right now!
normalised: Now, most people think about coding first, and yeah, programming is a big part of it. Languages like Python, Java, C plus plus are like the bread and butter of the industry. Seriously, learning Python will get you far, especially if you're interested in things like data science or A-I slash M-L (Artificial Intelligence slash Machine Learning). And trust me, those fields are hot right now!

unnormalised: But IT isn't just about coding. There's also network engineering – making sure that computers can talk to each other – which involves things like routers, switches, and firewalls. Plus, security is HUGE – protecting systems from hackers. Ethical hacking is another popular specialization!
normalised: But I-T isn't just about coding. There's also network engineering – making sure that computers can talk to each other – which involves things like routers, switches, and firewalls. Plus, security is huge – protecting systems from hackers. Ethical hacking is another popular specialization!

unnormalised: Then there's database management. You know, all that data has to live somewhere. People who work with databases like MySQL, PostgreSQL, or Oracle are super in demand. Especially with cloud computing becoming a standard. Companies like AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud are changing the whole game!

Especially with cloud computing becoming a standard. Companies like A-W-S, Azure, and Google Cloud are changing the whole game!

unnormalised: And let's not forget about the "IT support" roles. Someone needs to fix your computer when it crashes, right? And the salary range varies based on the level of expertise of course. Many freshers can earn upto Rs. 3.5 LPA in Indian IT industry.
normalised: And let's not forget about the "I-T support" roles. Someone needs to fix your computer when it crashes, right? And the salary range varies based on the level of expertise of course. Many freshers can earn up to rupees three point five lakh per annum in Indian I-T industry.

unnormalised: So, what should YOU do? My advice? Experiment! Try out some different things. There are tons of free resources online – Codecademy, Coursera, YouTube tutorials (many in Hindi too!). And of course, don't be afraid to ask questions. The IT community is generally pretty supportive.

unnormalised: If you are aiming for jobs in Google, Microsoft, or Amazon, keep an eye on their career page. Companies often hold recruitment drives in cities such as Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Chennai.
normalised: If you are aiming for jobs in Google, Microsoft, or Amazon, keep an eye on their career page. Companies often hold recruitment drives in cities such as Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Chennai.

unnormalised: Also, remember that having certifications can really boost your resume. Certifications from Cisco, Microsoft, or CompTIA can show employers that you have the skills they're looking for.

unnormalised: Finally, network! Go to meetups, join online communities, and connect with people on LinkedIn. You never know where your next opportunity might come from. And don't let the vastness of the field intimidate you. Take it one step at a time. Good luck! You got this!
